author: NoahNeedleman
content:
So there’s an old saying: if you wanna really know something, you gotta learn it, you gotta do it, then you gotta teach it. 

My friend who mentioned wanting to learn how to mix yesterday was amazed at how fast I was able to make his track sound big and loud and open all at the same time. “My mix sounded so small and congested. Yours sounds huge.”


Basically what I did, besides level & panning, was carve out a bunch of like 400 in all harmonic elements. All the tracks sounded good, but the density was all bunched up down in that range. 

As I was explaining it to him, I had a moment of clarity about headroom. Doesn’t matter if all frequencies are present for a big and tall mix, if all the headroom is getting eaten up by everything hitting the same frequencies, the collective volume of that is gonna make everything else feel quieter. 

I usually think of headroom in regard to low end and transients, but it’s true for every part of a mix.

author: Slow Hand
content:
A recent lesson that I've had to remind myself about was the importance of narrowing my long reverbs. Recently I've had a bad habit of keeping them full-width.

I've found that it really helps my soundstage if I don't let the long verbs touch the far-left or far-right of my mix. The more I narrow my verbs the deeper it feels like my sound stage will go. Like a vanishing point on the horizon. It also opens up a lot more sonic real-estate because now elements that are panned don't have to compete with a wide reverb wash.

Keeping those big verbs away from the extreme edges of my soundstage also creates contrast against my hard-panned elements and make them feel more forward.

I think this is an area where Soothe excels for me. 

My general method: 

1. LISTEN and identify before opening Soothe. Make a mental note of where the problem lies in the frequency spectrum. Get very specific. 

2. Open up soothe and use the filters to target that narrow area. Play around with the attack & sharpness and dial in the depth until the problem starts diminishing. 

3. Often, that general area will feel a tad bit dull. If so, boost the area with a wide bell to bring back all the good stuff now that the weird spiky resonances are dealt with.

author: JakeTB
content:
All of @popaganda. 's info is great here. To go one step further on the controls for a beginner- If you are using eq, that implies that you have already diagnosed a problem, which you'll be solving with eq. When you think of that problem, what words do you use? (i.e., this is way too dark, this needs a little more highs, that frequency hurts, etc.). 
If you find yourself talking about broader things like "highs" or "lows", that probably indicates a wide Q is appropriate. If you find yourself talking about "that ringing" or "the fundamental", that probably indicates a narrow Q is appropriate. 

Frequency, Bandwidth (Q), and Gain are all balance elements, as eq is a tool for balancing frequencies with one another. I'd avoid using the key of the song or phase when considering eq choices as a beginner. Just train and trust your ears.

A tool that can be helpful in training your ears for EQ usage is "Blindfold EQ" by Audiothing (https://www.audiothing.net/effects/blindfold-eq/), which is a free EQ plugin with no numbers or indicators for the controls.

author: Slow Hand
content:
This reminds me of an important point: Most sounds in the mix don't actually need to be stereo. And a snare drum is probably not one of them. You can create a lot of space in your mix by reducing all but a few key elements to mono. Keyboards and synths are a huge offender here.

A lot of mixers/producers assume that the instruments need to be stereo, when in fact it's the *mix* that should be stereo. And the most "stereo" mix is often created by panning mono instruments in the stereo field. Getting those pan balances right is going to remove a lot of conflict between instruments sharing similar frequency ranges.

You can still have stereo reverbs and echoes, but they can often be far more narrow than the default setting of 100% width. So don't overlook narrowing your stereo elements too.

It's amazing how much you can do with nothing but faders, pan knobs, and EQ.

If using verb as an insert on an instrument:

author: NoahNeedleman

Cian’s note on pokey frequencies is great. I mix banjo a lot (country music,) and I’ve got a couple thoughts that might be helpful if you’re not already finished. 
1) choose the top carefully. Where the “brightness” of the track is changes so much of how it’s perceived in the track. Chances are the top end is actually much lower than you’d expect. 
2) try compressing the shit out of it. Squash it allll to hell, kill the dynamics, RUIN the performance. There’s a good chance if it’s performed well it’ll turn into a punchy percussive element that adds size and excitement. 
3) make sure it’s balanced with another instrument on the other side of the the stereo field. If you don’t have one that’s playing something similar or has a similar top end, give it the old mono-verb/delay and see if that helps balance and keep it from being too distracting.
Hope that helps!

It’s hard to predict what’s going to happen in any case, so for me it’s about doing the science with your science hat on, taking a break, then fucking around with options until the voodoo clicks.

I think, again, it’s knowing the reason you’re using the tool, it’s mostly used when you want to accomplish something on the sides or in the mono signal when you can’t get to the track that needs the help, if your mixing, you should go to the track that needs the work first, not a M/S tool, M/S tools are designed for working on stereo tracks and shaping things because you CANT shape the original thing you want.

Example, the vocal is a little quiet in the mix, using a M/S tool to help bring the 1-2k of the vocal out in the mid without bringing out too much 1-2k of the cymbals and guitars on the sides because that balance was already where you wanted it. In this situation you can’t get to the vocal because you don’t have the track, BUT if you’re mixing, you can reach for the vocal and boost a narrow Q at 1500hz to accomplish the same task but in a cleaner way.

This is the type of reason I might reach for M/S, I don’t reach for M/S if guitars need to be brighter on the sides, I find the guitars on the sides in my mix, and make them brighter.

This is also the same reason to argue against multiple bus processing, because if the ability to use such a processor is there, we will use it, take away a bus and we have to work harder to get the mix done, but the end result can be much more effective, impactful, dynamic, and inspiring, but it takes longer and requires a lot more finesse.

author: Rob Domos
content:
Sure! RX is using FFT based processing.  (Worth googling and doing a deep dive if anyone is unfamiliar)

As a general rule with FFTs (and with EQ!!), the more narrow a selection is in the frequency domain, the wider it is time domain. This is an inviolable math law we can’t get around. 

How many bands the FFT is using has big implications for this, because the more bands there are, the more narrow the frequency impact can be, which means the wider the time impact has to be. 

You can make what looks like a very short selection in the time domain in RX, but if the FFT selection is set to the maximum amount of bands, you’re going to be effecting a ton of information to the left and right of your selection. Similarly, you can select just one narrow frequency but if you have the minimum amount of bands selected you’ll be turning down a whole bell the size of a half an octave

author: Colin Althaus
content:
I’ve found this often has to do with phase artifacts in M-S processing causing the image to sum together in odd ways (sometimes even ending up on the opposite side!)

Think of M-S processing like algebra. When converting left-right to mid-side (which is really sum-difference):

M = L + R
S = L - R

To reconstruct L and R,
L = 0.5(M + S)
R = 0.5(M - S)

So whether something appears on L or R is determined by its phase relationship on the S channel (+S or -S) relative to the M channel.

Flip the polarity of the whole S channel (+S to -S) and the whole image reverses: L becomes R, and R becomes L.

Now imagine a steep filter like a 24dB/oct HPF… here is a screenshot of the measured phase response. At the corner frequency of 100Hz we see the signal is 180 degrees out of phase.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
The thing that has changed is how many more people have the tools to make records. That has both sped up the process and reduced the quality control. These are related ideas but not the same.

Because people can create and put out music quickly, there is a lot more competition for making everything happen quickly, even for major labels. They are trying to compete with the overall speed of content output. This means that the length of time people have to live with mixes and masters is much shorter. So people miss things more easily.

This speed affects quality control as described, but there is another aspect. Because the number of people who can produce mix and master records has increased dramatically, that narrow funnel of sonic gate keepers no longer exists. There are probably 100x or 1000x as many capable mixers than there were 20 years. Same with producers, songwriters, artists, whatever.

Philosophically, I love this. But of course, the quality of recordings now varies much more than it used to.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
So think of mid vs side in terms of panning left right & center, and think of EQ as volume. 

If you’ve got a lot of low end information on the sides, and say it’s fighting with a mono bass track that’s supposed to be holding down the majority of the low end, you can eq the lows out of those panned tracks, or you can blanket turn all the lows down on the sides with a m/s eq on a buss, so that the L and R info is quieter. It’s basically a group volume ride for frequencies instead of tracks. You can also do this on individual stereo tracks if just panning isn’t granular enough. 

The why & when is mostly about taste. I tend to mix into a proQ3 setting that has the sides hi passed around 100 for the same reason I have a pultec boosting highs & lows on the master- it just ends up doing a lot of work for me.

It can become problematic if I’ve got big toms in a song and, after I’ve got a mix starting to cook I’ll toggle it on & off to see if I’m doing more harm than good. For the kind of music I mostly do, it works more often than not, but the one song I sent to Cian for mixing he basically blasted me for doing that. (In his own kind and gentle way.)

But m/s eq isn’t just for the master buss. You can think about it for any stereo track. Sometimes, I have an acoustic that’s carrying the whole song, but the fundamentals are fighting with the vocal, so I’ll turn the mid down at that frequency (or side chain that to the vocal if it feels anemic when the vocal is out.) that leaves the sides as big as you like cause it’s not fighting with my mono vocal.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
Great, we’ve all kind of known that. Back to FFT, which works in a LINEAR  way. If we run a 16 “band” FFT on a 48 kHz signal it will divide the audio spectrum (0 Hz to 24 kHz) into 16 evenly spaced bins or bands. Each bin is 1500 Hz wide. Think about that for a second. That means we have a a single bin that contains everything from 16500 to 18000 Hz, a very “narrow” slice as it pertains to musical interest. On the flip side we are left with only a single bin that represents everything from 0 Hz to 1500 Hz, a huge chunk of the music. If the whole point was to slice up this signal so we could do something interesting to it then that is often not the resolution we hoped for. 

I see the hands going up!! “Let’s just increase the number of bands to get more frequency resolution”. And herein lies one of the confounding things about FFT. We are caught in a frequency domain/time domain tradeoff. The finer the bands or slices the more things blur in the time domain when we reconstitute via the iFFT (of the bands we have processed any or all bands). If no processing then you can run any length FFT and then the iFFT and perfectly reconstruct the original signal. (This is what you’ll often see 16 to 48k FFT on signal meters).

So some practical examples to help you guys get a handle on this. Open a file in RX and get the spectral repair module in attenuate mode set to a strength of 1. Set bands to the lowest possible (128?), figure out how wide your bins are. Now try to do a detailed edit in the low end, you’ll notice that you don’t have much “resolution”, but up high say above 10k it’s razor sharp. Now bump up your bands to the max 4096. Do the same LF edit and you’ll suddenly have nice narrow frequency slices but you’ll see things getting very blurry in the time domain, tight kicks become smeary whooshes

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Depth in a mix is fairly simple, if you can hear it. You have a few basic tools and a few more complex ones, but overall it looks like this. 

Brighter+louder=closer
Darker+quieter=further

This is also true for bottom end *mostly.*

Panning also pushes things out of the center and allows you to play with a lot more area in which to push things back. 

If you don’t have the luxury of panning, as with a snare drum, then you have volume & eq as your main tools. 

Then you have reverb. Shorter predelay, fewer short reflections & louder tails. Choosing a larger algo like a hall, etc.
